title: I have heard two translations of Israel, 'wrestles with God' and 'Let God prevail'. How are these two translations distinct, and how do they reinforce each other? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some scholars do indeed understand the etymology of Hebrew Israel יִשְׂרָאֵל îśrā-΄ēl as “He wrestles/ struggles with God (El),” based on the night Jacob spent wrestling with an angelic representative of God at Peniel (Gen 32:24–31). Of course that may be a folk-etymology based on the etiology of a dietary prohibition (Gen 32:32), or it may have a hidden esoteric ritual meaning. The same name appears in Egyptian hieroglyphs as YsriЗr “Israel,” in line 27 of the Merneptah Stele.[1]  A better approach is grammatical and heavily based on linguistic comparison with similar Hebrew names: Hebrew Ishmael יִשְׁמָעֵאל îšmˁā-ʼēl “May-El (God)-hear!” E. A. Knauf analyzed this typical Semitic name as an imperfect verb with a theophoric subject.[2] It was the personal name of (a) the son of Abraham and Hagar (Genesis 25:11-18), and (b) a member of the royal court, son of Nethaniah ben Elishama – who assassinated Governor Gedaliah, and then escaped to Ammon in Transjordan (Jeremiah 41:1ff; cf. Ezra 10:22). This is the same name as earlier Amorite Yiśmaˁil, which in later biblical Hebrew is a reflex of ʼĕlîšāmˁā (KJV Elishama). David Noel Freedman proposed that Jacob is actually short for Jacob-El as Yaˁaqub-‘el “May-El-Protect (him)!” as possibly in Deuteronomy 33:28,[3] and as in the name of the Canaanite Hyksos ruler Yaˁqub-hr / Yaˁqub-ˁr “May-the-Exalted-One-Protect!”[4] These comparisons certainly make it likely that Israel may actually have the same hortative meaning “Let-God-Prevail, May-God-Prevail.”  [1] Merneptah Stele - Wikipedia . [2] E. A. Knauf, “Ishmaelites,” in Freedman, ed., Anchor Bible Dictionary, III:514. [3] D. N. Freedman, “The Original Name of Jacob,” Israel Exploration Journal, 13 (1963):125-126; John Bright, A History of Israel, 2nd ed., 91, 98; 3rd ed., 93. [4] William Ward in O. Tufnell, Scarabs and their Contribution to History in the Early Second Millennium B.C. (Warminster, 1984), 68, fig. 29; Ryholt, Political Situation, 44; Krauss, A&L (1998), 41.

Check your Bible. Book of Genesis The story when Jacob return back crossing the river in order to find few forgotten instruments. He finds the angel and clash , wrestling with him, and he prevail, he begs to be released by him as Morningstar is about to appear in the horizon.he blessed him and he returns back to his family. English version. Translation so so. That night Jacob got up and took his two wives, his two maidservants and his eleven sons and crossed the ford of the Jabbok. 23 After he had sent them across the stream, he sent over all his possessions. 24 So Jacob was left alone, and a man wrestled with him till daybreak. 25 When the man saw that he could not overpower him, he touched the socket of Jacob's hip so that his hip was wrenched as he wrestled with the man. 26 Then the man said, "Let me go, for it is daybreak." But Jacob replied, "I will not let you go unless you bless me." 27 The man asked him, "What is your name?" "Jacob," he answered. 28 Then the man said, "Your name will no longer be Jacob, but Israel, [5] because you have struggled with God and with men and have overcome." 29 Jacob said, "Please tell me your name." But he replied, "Why do you ask my name?" Then he blessed him there. 30 So Jacob called the place Peniel, [6] saying, "It is because I saw God face to face, and yet my life was spared." 31 The sun rose above him as he passed Peniel, [7] and he was limping because of his hip. 32 Therefore to this day the Israelites do not eat the tendon attached to the socket of the hip, because the socket of Jacob's hip was touched near the tendon. The Hebrew true origin. וַיִּוָּתֵר יַעֲקֹב לְבַדּוֹ, וַיֵּאָבֵק אִישׁ עִמּוֹ עַד עֲלוֹת הַשָּׁחַר. כו וַיַּרְא כִּי לֹא יָכֹל לוֹ, וַיִּגַּע בְּכַף יְרֵכוֹ, וַתֵּקַע כַּף יֶרֶךְ יַעֲקֹב בְּהֵאָבְקוֹ עִמּוֹ. כז וַיֹּאמֶר: "שַׁלְּחֵנִי כִּי עָלָה הַשָּׁחַר", וַיֹּאמֶר: "לֹא אֲשַׁלֵּחֲךָ כִּי אִם בֵּרַכְתָּנִי". כח וַיֹּאמֶר אֵלָיו: "מַה שְּׁמֶךָ?", וַיֹּאמֶר: "יַעֲקֹב". כט וַיֹּאמֶר: "לֹא יַעֲקֹב יֵאָמֵר עוֹד שִׁמְךָ, כִּי אִם יִשְׂרָאֵל, כִּי שָׂרִיתָ עִם אֱלֹהִים וְעִם אֲנָשִׁים וַתּוּכָל". ל וַיִּשְׁאַל יַעֲקֹב וַיֹּאמֶר: "הַגִּידָה נָּא שְׁמֶךָ", וַיֹּאמֶר: "לָמָּה זֶּה תִּשְׁאַל לִשְׁמִי?", וַיְבָרֶךְ אֹתוֹ שָׁם. לא וַיִּקְרָא יַעֲקֹב שֵׁם הַמָּקוֹם 'פְּנִיאֵל', "כִּי רָאִיתִי אֱלֹהִים פָּנִים אֶל פָּנִים וַתִּנָּצֵל נַפְשִׁי". לב וַיִּזְרַח לוֹ הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ כַּאֲשֶׁר עָבַר אֶת פְּנוּאֵל, וְהוּא צֹלֵעַ עַל יְרֵכוֹ. לג עַל כֵּן לֹא יֹאכְלוּ בְנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אֶת גִּיד הַנָּשֶׁה אֲשֶׁר עַל כַּף הַיָּרֵךְ עַד הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה, כִּי נָגַע בְּכַף יֶרֶךְ יַעֲקֹב בְּגִיד הַנָּשֶׁה.
